Secondly, as far as the three-cylinder engine is concerned that you alluded to, Dr. Reithofer, is it just going to be gasoline or as well, diesel? Is that going to be a whole new construction or is that a shortening of a four-cylinder version that is already existing?

And finally, maybe more on Mr. Eichiner's side. As far as EBIT and auto free cash flow on an adjusted level in 2010 are concerned, I am under the impression, and please correct me if I am wrong, that the EBIT development intra-year is more back-end loaded. But how would I imagine the development of adjusted free cash flow in this year, on an entry year basis? Thanks.
Thank you very much. We'll start with Norbert Reithofer.

I mean, as I said, it will be a modular system for BMW and MINI engines for the future. And I said, it will be a flexible system from three- to four- to six-cylinder and between petrol and diesel engines and of course, you asked the question, you will receive a straight answer. Three-cylinder engines will be petrol and diesel.

It will be again, it will be a modular system and it will give us very good economies of scale. And let me say, if you would like to be from a business point of view, a good cooperation partner, then you have to think first what is good for your company to stay independent and they you can ask yourself, can I generate more economies of scale if I have even on top a cooperation partner? If you need desperately a cooperation partner, you will not be a independent company anymore.
Okay. Second part, smaller cars, our targets 2012, Mr. Eichiner?

I mean, important for us, strategy in '12, as I mentioned today, is that we're not only producing small cars, that the segments starting with the 3 Series upwards will grow at the same point in time. But clearly, you are right, we have a focus to, as Dr. Reithofer said, in order to really benefit from development in the lower segment and that is strategically very important for us. We need to get younger people associated to our brand and when we have them in our value chain, we can sell them up. So that is basically a strategic point as well to offer cars in those segments.

Our approach is to come up with a, I don't want to say platform, with a kind of a flexible, K-Tech flexible modular system and the ways that we are combining MINI volumes together with new cars on the BMW side and shift – and bring the volume into a much higher level than today. So you look at the numbers we can sell on our front-wheel platform with MINI, with the blend we have in place, this will triple.

And with a tripling of those volumes, we should have better economy of scale and a better payback. So we should be in a much better position when it comes to the profitability of those small cars. All in all, I can say we evaluated that in our long-range planning very thoroughly and we should be able after 2012 to maintain the profitability level, if nothing seriously happens to the economy or to currencies. But everything is going in the wrong direction, which is still something that is important on the assumption side. So that's the plan for that.

Now 2010, you're right, we will be more back-end loaded. I wouldn't say only back-end, I think with the introduction, the second quarter could already benefit. Then usually third quarter, we have summer break, it is a bit weaker and then again, we have a full volume available in the fourth quarter. So this is more or less what we are expecting in the course of 2010.

Our target is and I think we will achieve that, to really be positive on the EBIT side of course in every and each quarter. That is true for the first quarter as well, but be profitable, grow over the course of the year and the first quarter will be possibly the lowest one. The same is more or less than true for free cash flow development. And we have to see how we balance this in the first quarter and then we get more and more momentum coming in from the growing operational cash flow. So that's how we see it. Hope that's okay for you.
Okay. Last question, John Buckland.

Thanks very much. John Buckland with MF Global. Just to go back to John's question about the cost of liquidity and the lack of financial income in the Auto division, perhaps you could answer that question, when will there be a reasonable contribution from holding all this cash?

But my main question relates to how the shareholders are going to benefit from the much improved profitability, if you deliver it and the cash flow, if you deliver it? In the late 2009-2010, you're obviously giving some of that money to externalize the pension. But how – what can you tell shareholders about what proportion and what mechanisms you will use to pay the shareholders to participate in this much improved outlook?
Mr. Eichiner?

Well, clearly, we – you know we have a stakeholder-orientated approach in our company and shareholders are very important for us. And you can see that because we nearly – the dividend payment we do in the crisis year '09, I think it was a clear signal that we want to see our shareholders participating in the success of the company.

But first of all, we have to be – we have to have success, we have to have a higher EBIT. And this has to be achieved in 2010. And I can tell you, our strategy is not to come back to a 20% ratio on dividends we had in the years before 2007. So it will clearly be a bigger share that we are prepared to give to our shareholders. It will not be at the 98% level we have for 2009, that I can say as well, but we will grow that share and let our shareholders participate.

Now coming back to the relation between the Auto segment and Financial Services, and I really want you to understand that we see it as a really captive combined business. I mean if you really have 40 – 50% of your costs financed, you need financing. And that's why we don't see a problem that we are using cash generated in Auto to support financing on the Financial Services side, because this gives Auto again the opportunity to sell more cars and it's generating cash again. So that is a momentum which we are using and it's still a part of our financing strategy and I don't see a reason why we should change it.
So thank you very much. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to close our meeting today. Thank you very much for your attention and now, we have lunch together.
